newsitem.title: New zealand: Wellington Airport closed after Cessna crash.
newsitem.headline: Wellington Airport closed after Cessna crash.

text.p: Wellington Airport remained closed at 12.30 p.m. on Monday, following the crash of a light plane on take-off around 10.15 a.m.
The New Zealand Press Association reported that the plane, a Cessna 185, was believed to be owned by Soundsair founder Cliff Marchant.

NZPA said it careered off the runway when a wheel collapsed after an axle failure. It said the two people on board the Cessna 185, which was believed to have been operating privately, were not injured in the crash.
Police, Fire Service, ambulance officers and the airport's rescue crash team were at the scene.
Cook Strait airline Soundsair has been grounded by the Civil Aviation Authority pending an investigation into safety issues.
Marchant is an Air New Zealand international pilot and uses the Cessna to fly to his home in the Marlborough Sounds.
Civil Aviation Authority deputy director Max Stevens said the Cessna was being operated privately at the time and was not on a passenger flight.
Although the aircraft had been used in Soundsair's operations, the authority's "initial reaction" was that it was on a private flight and had nothing to do with the grounded company.
The Transport Accident Investigation Commission would be looking into the crash, Stevens said.
